awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Genome Evolution of Amoebozoa: Resolving the deep phylogeny of Amoebozoa through genomic and proteomic features.
awd_abstract_narration:
Microscopic organisms have played an instrumental role in our understanding of many cellular processes. They constitute the majority of all living organisms, yet little is known about their diversity, behavior and genomics. This project focuses on amoeboid organisms belonging to the supergroup Amoebozoa. They exist in diverse natural habitats including marine, freshwater, and soil environments, and as symbionts or parasites affecting livestock and humans. Amoebozoans have long been considered simple and primitive, but recent studies have shown that they are more complex than previously thought. Despite their evolutionary and ecological significance, the biodiversity and evolution of Amoebozoans is not well understood. This project uses a combination of methods including whole genome analysis and advanced microscopy to resolve their phylogeny (how they are related to each other). The project will also examine key evolutionary features such as genome size and complexity as well as mechanisms of amoeboid movement. Knowledge of amoeboid movement has broad implications beyond Amoebozoans. It will give insights into groups that employ similar locomotive mechanisms, such as mammalian cells including macrophages and cancer cells. This project will also provide interdisciplinary training for women of African American origin and a postdoctoral fellow in advanced microscopy, genomics, proteomics, phylogenomics and microbial diversity.


Recent molecular studies made significant progress in our understanding of Amoebozoan diversity and evolution. However, the deep relationships among Amoebozoan subgroups are largely unresolved and some key lineages remain unplaced in the tree of Amoebozoa. The supergroup Amoebozoa is an old lineage, estimated to have evolved from a common ancestor over a billion years ago. Resolving ancient relationships is a difficult endeavor due to limited data and other historic and algorithmic challenges. This project will use a combination of approaches including cellular proteomic and whole genome sequencing to resolve the tree of Amoebozoa. Genome sequencing will provide not only large amounts of genetic data helpful for resolving the tree of Amoebozoa but also additional genomic architectural data that can be used to study the evolution of the group. Given that Amoebozoa holds a key evolutionary position in the tree of life, resolving the tree of Amoebozoa will elucidate many fundamental evolutionary questions including the origin and evolution of life cycles, multicellularity, host-parasite interactions, amoeboid movement, and horizontal gene transfer (HGT) across domains. In addition to this, study of Amoebozoan genomes and their complexity will give insights on how genome size impacts behavior and adaptation to various ecological niches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award facilitated research that employed whole genome sequencing and cellular proteomic characteristics to unravel the evolutionary history of one of the primary supergroups among eukaryotes, namely, the Amoebozoa. Amoebozoans are microscopic eukaryotes that move by the formation of temporary cytoplasmic projections called pseudopodia (false feet). The supergroup encompasses lineages characterized by extreme morphological, behavioral, and genomic diversity. This makes Amoebozoa ideal for the study of macroevolutionary trajectories of several commonly shared eukaryotic features and cellular processes, such as amoeboid movement, cell forms, sexual development, multicellularity, and genome size and complexity. Amoebozoa is the closest relative of the supergroup containing animals and fungi (Opisthokonts) and is considered to include lineages with the largest genome size of all known living forms. While our understanding of the group is steadily increasing with the analysis of more genetic data, the deep relationships within the group are not well understood. Moreover, Amoebozoa and many of its subgroups lack group-defining characters. This makes it difficult to accurately place enigmatic (problematic) taxa and evaluate anomalous or novel relationships in molecular-based phylogenies. Genome evolution in the group is poorly known due to the lack of data representing the major lineages. A comprehensive genome sequencing of poorly sampled lineages of the group, coupled with cytoskeletal data, will help elucidate the evolution of the group in general and place enigmatic taxa in their natural phylogenetic position. Genomic and cytological features can also help us understand existing and novel relationships that lack defining shared characters.

The project generated 15 draft genomes covering the three major clades of the Amoebozoa, substantially increasing genomic data for understudied and non-model amoebae lineages. This led to substantial progress in our understanding of the group's evolution, including the discovery of a novel deep-level relationship, the Divosa hypothesis, and the confirmation of the ancestral nature of sexuality in the group. The data also revealed variations in the mechanism of sex at the genetic level and extensive gene trafficking from bacteria and giant viruses through various processes. The novel deep-level hypothesis, the Divosa, is supported by the largest gene sampling to date in the group. It is supported by both morphological and molecular data, unlike the two previous hypotheses, which were solely based on morphology (Lobosa) and molecular data (Tevosa). This new hypothesis will help us to evaluate some of the major evolutionary events within the group. For example, comparative genomic analysis has not only reaffirmed the ancestral nature of sexuality in the group but has also revealed variations in the mechanism of sex at the genetic level. Our data is further elucidating the genome makeup and evolution of the group, including extensive gene trafficking from bacteria and giant viruses through various processes. The generated data has opened up research opportunities to study the molecular evolution of key genes and pathways that have played a role in the evolution and ecological success of the group.

The project has provided valuable training opportunities for three postdoctoral researchers and over 80 undergraduate researchers, particularly from minority and women backgrounds. This has resulted in 64 undergraduate presentations and the inclusion of seven undergraduates as co-authors in six peer-reviewed publications. The students received training in a variety of techniques, including molecular methodologies, immunocytochemistry, fluorescence microscopy, genome sequencing, and bioinformatics programming skills for genomic data manipulation. Two students also participated in a summer research program with collaborating colleagues at UCLA, which exposed them to broader scientific endeavors. The project also extended its impact to local middle and high school students through educational videos and practical exercises involving water samples. This gave them a taste of college-level experiences and hands-on laboratory engagement in the realm of freshwater microbial diversity. The project played a pivotal role in generating extensive genomic data that is crucial for the subsequent analysis of amoebozoans. In addition, the team deposited live cultures of newly identified amoebas in a culture collection agency to support future research endeavors.
